verses.text: It is actually reported among you that there is sexual immorality, and such immorality as is not even tolerated among the pagans—a man has his father’s wife.
verses.comment: The sin described refers to incest, specifically forbidden in the Law of Moses—see Leviticus 18:8. Early Christian communities strove for moral purity, notably surpassing pagan standards. The seriousness of church discipline is introduced here.

verses.text: And you are proud! Should you not rather have mourned, so that the one who has done this deed would be removed from among you?
verses.comment: Paul’s rebuke echoes Christ’s teaching about mourning over sin and practicing discipline (see Matthew 18:17). Paul here expects a deep sense of communal responsibility—implicating a visible, authoritative body.

verses.text: For though I am absent in body, I am present in spirit; and as if present, I have already judged the one who has so acted.
verses.comment: Paul shows that spiritual authority transcends physical presence, supporting the idea of an ongoing, visible leadership structure.

verses.text: When you are assembled in the name of our Lord Jesus, and my spirit is present, with the power of our Lord Jesus,
verses.comment: The communal gathering, invoked in the Lord’s name, suggests real sacramental unity—a means by which the Lord’s authority is exercised among the faithful (see Matthew 18:20).

verses.text: you are to hand this man over to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, so that his spirit may be saved on the day of the Lord.
verses.comment: This refers to excommunication—a severe but medicinal act meant for repentance and ultimate salvation. Restoration and salvation remain the goal through this authoritative act.

verses.text: Your boasting is not good. Do you not know that a little leaven leavens the whole lump?
verses.comment: Paul uses leaven as a metaphor for sin—a motif from both Old and New Testaments (see Exodus 12:15; Galatians 5:9). Sin corrupts the whole community if left unchecked.

verses.text: Cleanse out the old leaven so that you may be a new batch, as you really are unleavened. For Christ, our Passover lamb, has been sacrificed.
verses.comment: Christ’s role as Passover lamb fulfills the Old Testament (Exodus 12; John 1:29) and connects the act of cleansing to participation in Christ’s sacrificial work—hinting at sanctifying rites.

verses.text: Therefore let us celebrate the feast, not with old leaven, the leaven of malice and evil, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.
verses.comment: Here is both literal and spiritual application—an exhortation to live genuinely, and a hint toward an ongoing, sacred communal celebration reflective of Old Testament feasts, fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: I wrote to you in my letter not to associate with sexually immoral people—
verses.comment: A previous letter referenced here, implying ongoing apostolic correspondence and instruction.

verses.text: not at all meaning the sexually immoral of this world, or the greedy and swindlers, or idolaters, for then you would have to leave the world.
verses.comment: Christians are called to engage with the world, not withdraw entirely. Jesus Himself prays for protection while remaining ‘in the world’ (cf. John 17:15).

verses.text: But now I am writing to you not to associate with anyone who claims to be a brother but is sexually immoral, greedy, an idolater, a slanderer, a drunkard, or a swindler—not even to eat with such a one.
verses.comment: The call is for discipline among self-identified believers. Notably, even sharing a meal—possibly an allusion to the Lord’s Supper—is forbidden, emphasizing the holiness expected within the visible Church.

verses.text: For what have I to do with judging outsiders? Is it not those inside the church whom you are to judge?
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes those ‘inside’ and ‘outside’ the visible assembly, reiterating the community’s authority and responsibility for internal discipline (cf. 1 Timothy 3:15, ‘pillar and foundation of the truth’).

verses.text: God judges those outside. 'Remove the evil person from among yourselves.'
verses.comment: Paul cites Deuteronomy, invoking God’s directive for communal purity. This evokes continuity between the people of God in the Old and New Covenants; discipline is enacted for the preservation of holiness.
